thread.title_full: Crows source says Patrick Dangerfield close to re-signing with Adelaide | The Advertiser

author: Kym Morgan
title: Crows source says Patrick Dangerfield close to re-signing with Adelaide |
text:
A SOURCE close to the Adelaide Football Club says Patrick Dangerfield is close to signing a long term deal tying him to West Lakes.
And the player’s manager says a decision on the midfielder’s future is imminent.
An AFL industry employee with close links to the Crows has told The Advertiser he believes Adelaide is now in the box seat in negotiations and has moved to within sight of a deal which would see Dangerfield remain at West Lakes for the best years of his career.
RUCCI: Rivalry solid but can Showdown change footy?
Dangerfield’s manager Paul Connors flew to Adelaide today and will meet with the Crows star this week. Sam Jacobs and Patrick Dangerfield hug after the Crows Showdown 39 win. Photo: Calum Robertson. Source: News Corp Australia
He hosed down talk of progress on a contract extension which would tie Dangerfield to West Lakes for up to five seasons and claimed not to have talked with the star about his future since the tragic death of former Crows coach Phil Walsh.
Connors said the pair would talk Tuesday about Dangerfield’s intentions going forward.
“I still don’t know what Patrick is doing next year, but I will know soon,’’ Connors said.
“I’m catching up with a couple of my players and will catch up with Patrick for a coffee.
“But it’s not unreasonable for Pat to say to me that it’s been an emotional period and I haven’t given it some thought lately and I was thinking one thing and I’m now thinking another.
“And I don’t think it’s unreasonable for him to be given time to work through this and not make a decision in an emotional state.” Danger splitting Port’s defence at Adelaide Oval. Source: AP
Dangerfield has publicly maintained he is concentrating only playing football but his body language in the aftermath of Walsh’s death has shown his close bond with teammates and the club.
The 25-year-old must weigh up whether to see through the journey the Crows embarked on when Walsh arrived this season or return to Victoria — with Geelong the leading suitor from over the border due to the midfielder’s close family ties in the region.
Money is understood not to be a motivating factor and the Crows will not pay over the odds to retain their star.
Adelaide also flat-batted questions Monday.
“We do not discuss player contract negotiations irrespective of who the player is,’’ a spokesman for the club said.
“It’s not the way we do business.”
- with Mark Robinson
